total_impedance_ori_txt.item: R1 and Re0 connected in series so Rd0=R1+Re0=4Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33Ohm
R2 and Rc0 connected in series so Rb0=R2+Rc0=5.33Ohm
Rb0 and R4 connected in series so Ra0=Rb0+R4=10.3Ohm

total_impedance_txt.item: R1 and Rf0 connected in series so Rd0=R1+Rf0=4Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33Ohm
R2 and Rc0 connected in series so Rb0=R2+Rc0=5.33Ohm
Rb0 and R4 connected in series so Ra0=Rb0+R4=10.3Ohm

total_impedance_ori_txt.item: R4 and Re1 connected in series so Rd1=R4+Re1=9Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.64Ohm
Rc1 and Rf1 connected in series so Rb1=Rc1+Rf1=2.64Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=5.64Ohm

total_impedance_txt.item: R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd1=R4+R2=9Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.64Ohm
Rc1 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=Rc1+R1=2.64Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=5.64Ohm

solution.item: *** Solution by TINA assisted by AI ***
We have more than one generator so we are using superposition to calculate voltages/currents.
>> Pass1 started ...
>> Gen processing: VS2 ...
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS2)
R1 and Rf0 connected in series so Rd0=R1+Rf0=4Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33Ohm
R2 and Rc0 connected in series so Rb0=R2+Rc0=5.33Ohm
Rb0 and R4 connected in series so Ra0=Rb0+R4=10.3Ohm
The total resistance is Ra0 = 10.3Ohm
Now we calculate the current on R5
We know that the voltage between VS2 nodes is 4V.
All voltage generators except for VS2 have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators have been replaced with an open circuit.
(1) The components Rb0,R4 connected in series.
(1) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 4V.
(1) Rb0 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb0 is Rb0/Ra0*4V = 2.06V.
(1) The current on Rb0 is the 'voltage on Rb0 / Rb0' = 387mA .
(2) The components R2,Rc0 connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 2.06V.
(2) Rc0 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rc0 is Rc0/Rb0*2.06V = 516mV.
(2) The current on Rc0 is the 'voltage on Rc0 / Rc0' = 387mA .
(3) The components R5,Rd0 connected in parallel. The voltage on R5 is 516mV because the voltage on Rc0 is 516mV
(3) The current on R5 is the 'voltage on R5 / R5' = 258mA .
>> Pass2 started ...
>> Gen processing: VS1 ...
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS1)
R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd1=R4+R2=9Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.64Ohm
Rc1 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=Rc1+R1=2.64Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=5.64Ohm
The total resistance is Ra1 = 5.64Ohm
Now we calculate the current on R5
We know that the voltage between VS1 nodes is 6V.
All voltage generators except for VS1 have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators have been replaced with an open circuit.
(4) The components R3,Rb1 connected in series.
(4) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 6V.
(4) Rb1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb1 is Rb1/Ra1*6V = 2.81V.
(4) The current on Rb1 is the 'voltage on Rb1 / Rb1' = 1.06A .
(5) The components Rc1,R1 connected in series.
(5) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 2.81V.
(5) Rc1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rc1 is Rc1/Rb1*2.81V = 1.74V.
(5) The current on Rc1 is the 'voltage on Rc1 / Rc1' = 1.06A .
(6) The components R5,Rd1 connected in parallel. The voltage on R5 is 1.74V because the voltage on Rc1 is 1.74V
(6) The current on R5 is the 'voltage on R5 / R5' = 871mA .
Now we are using superposition to calculate the current on R5
Let's summarize the calculations from the previous section.
When you see subtraction here it means that the original direction reversed.
'current on R5' = -129mA-194mA = -323mA
*** Wrong ***: expected: -1.13, got: -323m
